One of the best Backrooms games I've played. Please, let me know if you've played similar or better ones. üôèüèº

Nice game to play with friends, I recommend playing with friends and (if you are a little tryhard) then go play alone, it'll make you sweat a little. You could say that some levels are not according to the original lore, but if you do a pretty extensive search, you will find that everything is (or at least is almost) at point with the original lore.

[h1]Game which [b]MUST[/b] be played with friends[/h1][h3](or you're psycho)[/h3]

[hr][/hr]
[h2]In a nutshell[/h2]
[i]If you enjoy playing horror games which has puzzles ‚Äî trust me, you will like it, but don't forget 'bout your buddies![/i]

[b][i]Game was made for playing with friends[/i][/b], so I wouldn't recommend buying it if you're loner. Just compare two completely different types of gameplay: violent abusing of mics as someone's chased by an unknown entity accompanied by loud laughter and overall team play - or tense, thoughtful gameplay, accompanied by silence, solitude and ambient of the level.
Therefore, I [u][b]strongly recommend[/b][/u] exploring this game in the company of your [strike]braindead[/strike] friends.

[h2]Going into details[/h2]
I'll mention only main/needed aspects which may help users who need detailed analysis before buying:
[olist]
    [*]Gameplay
    [*]Graphics
    [*]SFX
    [*]Optimization
    [*]How fun was it to play (Based on friends opinions)
    [*]My opinion & conclusion
[/olist]
[b][i]BUT[/i][/b] if you're lazy to go through tons of text here's overall tab:
[table]
    [tr]
        [td][b]ASPECT[/b][/td]

        [td][u]How fun was it[/u][/td]
        [td]11/10[/td]
        [td]Proximity chat elevates multiplayer far beyond solo[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
Core gameplay based on [b]co-op exploration across 30+ backrooms levels[/b], including puzzles, navigation, and [strike]trash talking friends[/strike] running from [i]entities[/i]. Each level draws from creepypasta lore, featuring unique layouts like endless yellow rooms, electrical stations, cave systems, or flooded areas (poolrooms, thalassophobia). Puzzles vary: aligning electrical panels, searching for needed code in area, combining environmental items (e.g., keys, levers, tv's), or timing sequences under pressure.
There are no tons of mechanics, one of them is useless: leaning left/right. Also there's type of mechanics as sanity, which will go down over time, and go faster if you see something scary. You can restore it by consuming items like almond water, juice, energy bar, moth jelly [strike]or liquid death[/strike].

[h2]Graphics[/h2]
[i][b]Perfectly serviceable horror visuals[/b][/i], way sharper after 1.0 and now genuinely impressive for an indie backrooms game that doesn‚Äôt try to melt your GPU.
Classic mono-yellow hell is spot-on: endless damp carpets that look like they‚Äôve never been cleaned, wallpaper peeling like it‚Äôs trying to escape, and those buzzing fluorescent lights flickering in the exact rhythm that makes your eye twitch. The volumetric fog is thick enough to cut with a knife, legitimately hides corners and turns every hallway into a coin-flip between ‚Äúsafe‚Äù and ‚Äúrandom jumpscare‚Äù
[b][i]Entities[/i][/b] look properly unsettling: 
[list]
    [*][b]Smilers[/b] glow like discount neon signs from hell
    [*]These dog-like [b]Hounds[/b] look worse than my drunk uncle
    [*]Comically wired [b]Bacteria[/b] with long odd arms
    [*][b]Partygoers[/b] whose appearance and 7ft height genuinely scare shit outta you
    [*]Forgot 'bout [b]Skinstealers[/b] - entities which can [i]change[/i] their appearance to regular player, then turn into giant bulk monster and demolish you with single smash
[/list]
[b][i]Animations[/i][/b] are [i]smooth[/i] as butter, chases feel fast and scary, and ragdoll deaths occasionally produce accidental comedy gold. You literally explode and then your body lays on the floor without legs and arms like starfish.
Textures hold up close, post-processing is tasteful (light bloom, subtle vignette, just enough chromatic aberration to make everything feel ‚Äúoff‚Äù).
Doesn‚Äôt chase photorealism and doesn‚Äôt need to. Does [b]exactly[/b] what it has to do, nothing more, nothing less.

[h2]SFX[/h2]
[b][i]Exemplary spatial audio[/i][/b]. 3D sound positions footsteps, water splashes, and breaths directionally ‚Äî headphones are [u][b]REQUIRED[/b][/u]. No cheesy music, just subtle drones that creep under your skin like existential dread.
[i][b]Entity SFX not the best[/b][/i], but it does its function perfectly - [i]inspires fear[/i]. Hound's wet snarls of rabid dog, Skinstealers mimic warped voices as [i]"Hello?"[/i] which turns into a growl after few seconds, same with Partygoers, but they're ain't greeting you.
[i][b]Proximity VC[/b][/i] integrates seamlessly, with entities detecting raised voices for added risk. In group play, hearing teammate's panic heightens realism and sustain paranoia. 

[h2]Optimization[/h2]
[b][i]It is quite good[/i][/b], 'cause on my ancient pc (i7 920, 6gb ram, 1050ti) everything was great except few levels.
If your pc's better than mine, you can play on high settings without thinking about lags or freezes.

[h2]How fun was it to play (friends opinions)[/h2]
[quote=Max] it (8/10) [/quote]
[quote=Andrey] Game's peak, atmosphere slaps, would complete this game 19 times but mid updates (9/10) [/quote]
[quote=Michael] Pretty good if playing not alone (7/10) [/quote]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Sanity-draining exploration, clever puzzles, and entity chases that demand real teamwork via proximity chat. Great SFX and atmospheric visuals turn endless hallways into pure dread. Buttery optimization means your weak PC squad joins the panic without lag.
[i]Solo?[/i] It's playable but feels like wandering a party alone ‚Äî functional, yet missing the screams and chaos that makes it legendary.

[b]Final verdict: [u][i]HIGHLY RECOMMENDED[/i][/u] ‚Äî but grab the squad first, or stay a solo psycho forever[/b]

Finished the game with friends, and oh, I‚Äôve got some complaints.

I want to start with a few nice things. For starters, the game uses the Backrooms concept well ‚Äî the whole adaptation is alright and the levels are generally on point. The graphics are very nice, and the environments are genuinely enjoyable to look at ‚Äî some levels, like the Poolrooms, were incredibly immersive. The overall control and perceiving the game were executed comfortably, and one last good thing worth mentioning is that puzzle progress saves after dying.

But uh, the game is only moderately enjoyable with great friends. In our opinion, playing it solo would be insufferable. So here's a list of the things we found frustrating, without dwelling on each one too long:

- You're either lucky or unlucky, which often turns the game into a long spectating simulator ‚Äî made worse by the lack of voice chat for dead players.
- No storage spot to manage equipment efficiently, and too many items feel pointless.
- Sanity does not refresh between levels, so surviving one level usually just means you‚Äôre doomed early in the next one.
- Cannot refresh sanity as it's starting to eat you.
- On the flooded city level, sanity drains unless you‚Äôre piloting the boat, so you‚Äôre either alone and suffering irl, or on the boat with a friend and eventually die.
- The ID card feels pointless against mimics and is barely useful in general.
- Monsters poorly executed: weird mechanics, random deaths, random kill distances, repetitive, and almost no real counterplay besides being "lucky/unlucky". Models and death animations are also disappointing.
- Not particularly scary.
- Lacks novelty.
- Far too little almond water. 
- Instructions are sometimes overly direct‚Äîruining the fun‚Äîand other times completely absent when needed.

While I agree that this game can be fun, it mostly boils down to finding an item or activating a lever, with a few exceptions. Essentially, 60% of the game consists of variations on the same task and mechanic, while the remaining 40% feels slightly more unique.
Jank:
Player movement, animations, and character model behavior are basic - and let's be honest - janky. The AI is extremely simplistic and dumb: it follows a straight line along the nearest pathfinding lane and gets stuck on uneven terrain, or sometimes it goes where it shouldn't (like Clumps can drop into pools). The only differences between enemies are movement speed and the fact that some can be countered with the flashlight.
Levels:
The levels gradually improve in visual quality toward the end of the game. Even the reworked early levels don't show noticeable differences. In maps with hiding spots, the holes are either too large or too small, making them stand out awkwardly against the environment. The thalassophobia level and the moth-pipe level force you to wander aimlessly if you don't know the path (tested with multiple groups - our record for the pipe one was 1.5 hours of circling without progress). Also, thanks for the checkpoints; saving your location is nice, but respawning everyone at a previous checkpoint just because one player wandered there accidentally is even better, right?
Ending:
The ending is completely confusing. You finish the final level, hit a black loading screen, and then get an "unlocked ending" message before waking up in a room full of beds. Did you actually beat the game? Was that the real ending or just bait? Short answer: yes, you completed it. Feel free to Alt+F4 and uninstall - the experience and structure don't inspire replays. The funniest part? A simple prompt asking if you want to continue would have cleared up the confusion.
Conclusion:
In my opinion, the game is okay-ish - neither good nor bad. Yes, it's the dev's first full solo project, and sure, there are worse games out there for a higher price. But when I sat down to decide whether I'd give it a thumbs-up review, I kept thinking about my friends' disappointment after we waited eagerly for 1.0, only to replay the same underwhelming experience we had in Early Access. For me, it simply doesn't clear the bar of "good enough".
Additional developers joined late in development, and the hype train started, after a full year of radio silence on the Steam page. So what did they actually deliver? A handful of extra levels (hardly a game-changer), maybe some bug fixes (every EA bugs I reported are all still present), and... the removal of a few existing levels? No matter how hard I try, I just don't see a polished, finished product here.
If you like running around a maze until you get killed by a crappy looking monster that sounds like a dinosaur this game may be for you. It's just an over-hyped crappy indie game with no content.

DISCLAIMER: This review is mainly based on the disappointing 1.0 update. 

As I have been a long time fan of this game and its developer, it‚Äôs hard for me to say that this game has officially persuaded me to write a negative review. The 1.0 release was one of the most disappointing updates that I have ever seen in a game. We waited two years for an update half the size of previous updates that took half as long to release. In addition, on discord the developer promised features that never came to be, while updating us every 1-2 months max with barely any information, besides: UPDATE IS 99.99999999999% done, which had been the case for the past year. Promised us a console release, while claiming that the update had been finished since January 2025 and hadn‚Äôt been released due to ‚Äúconsole store requirements‚Äù, while then launching the game this October still without console support. 

TL;DR: The dev can no longer be trusted to give us accurate and consistent feedback on updates. 

Now on to the actual game:
The dev hired a group of individuals to help him polish his game, and while the update took nearly two years to release, there were far more bugs introduced than were removed. My friend and I had game-breaking bugs during our playthrough of the update, one of which being that we were unable to interact with many of the necessary items needed to complete the game, forcing us to scrap our save file after attempts to fix it. In regards to the ‚Äúnew‚Äù levels added, one is the new ‚Äúbase‚Äù area, which is not actual gameplay but rather an area that takes 20 seconds to walk through, another is a walking sim that takes about 5 minutes, one is based on a weak, easy knockoff of weeping angel mechanics, and the only one that is actually pretty good is another reskin of level 0 with entities we have already seen. 

This review has been completely negative, but I will say that the dev does at least ‚Äúseem‚Äù passionate about the game. If you haven‚Äôt played before it can be a fun experience, minus the bugs, especially when you are with friends.

This game is not enjoyable and is poorly designed for a player's experience.

It's a multiplayer, puzzle based exploration game. This would be a decent formula, except there's also player death with checkpoint-based respawns. This leads to a terrible and unenjoyable experience for players.

You're in a group of up to 4. When you die, you just sit there spectating someone who is alive until some predefined checkpoint. Given that the game is a mystery exploration, monsters are going to be a surprise with how they work. A player can't (and shouldn't) be expected the first time to understand how they work to avoid being killed. So, the game should be either forgiving with this in some way, or make it so that the players left alive are somehow on a timer to solve the puzzle/complete the level / get to a respawn point.
Otherwise, players that have died are just spectating, unable to help with the puzzle, unable to move around and explore, potentially indefinitely. This is just not fun and ruins the experience.

This game is not for me. To start, this is your typical Unreal Engine game, meaning its assets are unnecessarily detailed and there are a bunch of PBR effects that ultimately make the game look worse. The flashlight creates absolutely zero ambient lighting unless you're playing at very high graphics settings. It makes its surroundings either completely bright or completely dark, and when combined with bloom, makes the flashlight is as disorienting as it is useful. And there's your typical Unreal Engine Motion Blur‚Ñ¢ that makes you want to vomit yourself to sleep. Motion blur is absolutely [i]not[/i] something you want in a low-light game. There is no reason for this game to be 20 gigabytes in storage and run mediocre on an average graphics card.

The game is not scary. I don't personally find mutilated creatures creepy by default. A character does not need to be covered in human skin or be full of teeth to be scary. But this game relies heavily on that sort of definition of creepy. Effectively every character has the same gameplay loop: wander around its world and, upon spotting the player, chase them until they die or escape. After the first few creatures, it gets old. I do appreciate the various gimmicks added here and there. (Level 2 spoiler) [spoiler]The creature in the garage level that initially looks like a human can be spooky at times. Here's a suggestion: if the players are using voice chat, take small snippets of their conversation and play them from the creature when it is disguised. Try to convince the players its one of their friends. It would fit much further in the "uncanny valley" side of things and possibly produce a scarier effect.[/spoiler] But the character design is overall poor, and the animations certainly don't help things. Often times the death animations are too funny to be scared of. Ugly thingy makes funny faces and then Blue Screen Of Death "End Tape" Fade To White.

The game is not fun. You're going to die a lot in this game, and the actual gameplay loop becomes a chore once you've died in a level enough times. I played in hard mode with my friend because it felt unfair to keep playing when the other died. When either of us died, we both started over. The challenges the game requires you to do are interesting enough at the start of a level, but become fairly benine towards the end. (Level 3 spoiler) [spoiler]The dog level was particularly tedious. There were a certain number of electrical switches that were randomly placed across the level. Fair enough, could be cool. The problem is that it's a 5-10 minute endeavor to locate all of them, and when you die all three are reset. I'll give it credit, at least there are save points every set of three, but the last set of 3 took us almost two and a half hours alone to complete.[/spoiler] When it wasn't a "die or be dead" situation, it was a "wander around for a few minutes and chat situation," because there were zero enemies or obstacles of any kind. I'm not going to claim it was completely unenjoyable, but it became an entirely different game. It felt like we were accomplishing a task rather than playing a game. In many of the levels, our movements would become quite choreographed, we would execute a specific sequence of actions every time. Again, we found our own fun, but I wouldn't call this a successful horror experience by any means.

The game is unpolished. For the later creatures, there is either effectively no jumpscare sound or literally no jumpscare sound. The creature animations are pretty terrible, and the jumpscares are often just them wiggling their face at you or moving towards you at a medium pace. The third-person animations are equally as terrible/humorous. There are far fewer sounds in the game than there should be. Some levels have no ambient sound or music whatsoever. There are also plenty of bugs. The worst case being Level Fun. (Level Fun spoiler) [spoiler]I don't fully understand the glitch, but when targeting a player, if a monster clips the edge of a wall trying to chase the player, all currently aggro'd monsters freeze. This action is undone by crawling under a table, which cancels all aggro's. In addition, if a "fixed" monster comes in contact with a "broken" monster, both monsters become broken, leading to a cascading effect. This bug has been in the game since at least September 2022. Hell, they even replaced the models of the monsters without meaningfully fixing the bug.[/spoiler] There are also plenty of small bugs that occur here and there that overall reduce my immersion in the game. However, I'll admit that this is on the minor spectrum of things.

The game isn't the backrooms. Effectively every level after (Game progression spoiler) [spoiler]"The End"[/spoiler] feels like an entirely different game. It felt as if that level was intended to be the end, and then the game became popular and extra levels were slapped on top. Here are a few examples.

(Level [spoiler]"The End"[/spoiler] spoiler) [spoiler]The clown section blew me away with how completely and utterly unrelated to the backrooms it was. It was just straight-up a different horror experience. It was almost the [i]exact[/i] antithesis. Rather than being in a vast space that's easy to get lost in, the clown section is in a single open room. Rather than exploring and hoping not to get caught, it was better to shove myself in a corner and wait for the guy to try and attack. It also had such obvious intentions. As soon as you see the clown statue you know he's going to start moving and attacking you. It was never unexpected for a moment. The axe scene was a completely different style of horror than what is typically in internet creepypasta horror (the backrooms, SCP, you get it), being much more down-to-earth and physical. And after the roller coaster in the dark with the clown definitely still around and no exit opened, the map just claims that's a win state and calls it a day.[/spoiler]

(Level 6 spoiler) [spoiler]This level featured possibly the best gimmick in the entire game. I love the intention of the LiDAR scanner, and it's surprisingly polished as well. However, this absolutely does [b]NOT[/b] belong in a backrooms game! The implementation here was terrible. It was "navigate a complicated maze nearly completely blind, with zero meaningful landmarks, while a creature roams around and occasionally bumps into you." The creature itself was trivial to negate by simply being constantly crouched. When crouched, the creature won't kill you even if you're moving and it literally bumps into you. The insanity meter almost felt as if it depleted faster than normal, and when either one of us went insane we had to completely start from the beginning, with zero leftover dots. The implementation of LiDAR would have been much better if you had to do more than try and run from a fella. I think if you had to solve a simple puzzle or two in a smaller maze with more landmarks, that could be interesting. And completely get rid of the insanity meter, maybe the fella too, make the entertainment factor some other form of horror, or maybe not horror at all. But this obviously can't be done in a game that trys to be the backrooms. That's totally fine, but [b][i]this[/i] level should not be in [i]this[/i] game[/b].[/spoiler]

Overall, this game feels like a streamer game rather than a genuine attempt at good horror/game design. It suffers from similar fates as most other comedic multiplayer horror games (with some notable exceptions). There are Garry's Mod maps that capture the feeling of the backrooms better than this game. There are some genuinely good ideas in here for sure, but they're polluted by plenty of not-so-good game design choices. It's fun to play, but not for the purpose of immersion. It's fun to make fun of and occasionally be sick of together with a friend.

If you want a good horror experience, maybe pass on this one.

I got this game as a gift from a friend, and that's pretty good, because, in my humble opinion, if you are playing this game by yourself, it's not really worth it. 
Now, I must confess that the game by itself is not necessarily bad. It looks good, it runs well on my machine and, at some points, the gameplay can be quite entertaining (the castle level and hallway chase were very cool). Having said that, I found most of the levels to be unfun, sluggish and unexciting. This was not because of a lack of instruction or clarity; instead, most of my frustrations came from my personal biases in regards to the setting - which I believe is bland and uninteresting -, the tedious navigation and the boring puzzle structure.
The only reason I managed to play this game as long as I have (and also finish it while it was on early-access) is because I have neat friends which made the experience engaging enough for me to stick around. 
So, yeah. I really wouldn't recommend this game for solo-playing, but it could be an enjoyable (albeit a bit tedious) time with friends.
